awd_abstract_narration:
The development of chemical reactions to prepare organic molecules that are chiral, i.e., exist as non-superimposable mirror images, is vital to addressing human healthcare.  This is because most pharmaceutical molecules are chiral.  In this project, Dr. Meek is developing new catalytic reactions to make chiral molecules, using organic compounds containing carbon-carbon double bonds as building blocks.  Using new transition metal catalysts designed in his laboratory, Dr. Meek and his team are demonstrating that even unreactive double bonds can be transformed into important and useful chiral products.  Dr. Meek is actively engaged in outreach activities that build upon his research and open lines of communication between students interested in pursuing STEM careers, and more broadly serve to scientifically educate the general public.  These activities, which include editing online articles and increasing undergraduate participation, are directed at improving science education and encouraging students of all backgrounds to be exposed to the opportunities of STEM career pathways.


In this project, funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Meek and his team of graduate and undergraduate students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, design and develop new robust rhodium (Rh)-based catalysts that are easily accessible and promote the stereoselective addition of common organic nucleophiles to olefins.  Such hydrofunctionalization methods provide versatile and atom-economical approaches for the formation of new carbon-carbon and carbon-nitrogen bonds with minimal waste.  In general, these processes involve activation of readily available pi-bonds, and address issues concerning reaction site- and stereoselectivity.  High levels of selectivity are critical to synthesizing acyclic and cyclic molecular scaffolds that exhibit specific biological and physical properties, as well as rendering the resulting processes more time and cost effective.  Dr. Meek is actively engaged in STEM outreach activities that focus on broadening the dissemination of scientific concepts and increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in science.

por.por_cntn:
Overall Goals: Advances in biomedical research demand the precise preparation of organic molecules with defined overall shape and stereochemical identity as these characteristics can drastically alter the way organic molecules function and interact in biological systems. As a consequence, the invention of efficient and cost effective protocols to access organic molecules in a site- and stereoselective fashion is vital for scientists to be able to rapidly develop pharmaceutical lead compounds. Moreover, chemical processes that utilize readily available chemical starting materials (e.g., alkenes), incorporate desirable functionality, and employ earth abundant metal catalysts provide significant manufactural advantages. These essential principles served as the foundation of the investigations that were supported by the NSF in our laboratories.

Intellectual Merit: Alkenes are some of the most pervasive functional groups found in organic molecules, and catalytic reactions of alkenes are some of the most widely utilized transformations that have had a significant impact on the manufacture of pharmaceuticals. Consequently, design and development of new chemical processes that expand the use and synthesis of these types of groups is of vital importance to advancing new medicines and other areas of science.  

Summary of the outcomes: This NSF award is for the development of Stereoselective Hydrofunctionalization Reactions of Olefins. In the present funding period emphasis has been on catalysts for stereoselective formation of carbon–carbon bonds. The highlights of our accomplishments are: 

(1) Development of new ligands and catalysts for broadly applicable site- and stereoselective addition of heteroarene nucleophiles to dienes for synthesis of functionalized heteroaromatics, entities that are common to biological scaffolds.

(2) Development of transition metal catalysts that promote efficient alkene hydrofunctionalization for the site-selective coupling of unsaturated carbon nucleophiles with simple olefins.

(3) Identification and development of a variety of new earth abundant transition metal catalysts that convert simple olefin feedstock materials to valuable chiral arene containing entities.

(4) Development of efficient methods for the highly site- and stereoselective couplings of allyl groups with olefins promoted by sustainable earth abundant transition metal complexes.

Broader Impact: The fundamental and practical features of organic chemistry developed in this research program benefit both academic and industry chemists, by showing how reactions that employ abundant chemical feedstocks and sustainable catalysts provide important economic and manufactural advantages. For example, our work with earth abundant transition metals changes how solving synthesis problems in the pharmaceutical, polymer, and fragrance and food additive industries can be achieved. Additionally, our research stimulates aspects of catalyst design and areas of method development that are beyond the scope of this program. 

The PI is and his group are actively engaged in outreach activities, including increasing participation of undergraduate students of all backgrounds and incorporating broad educational components into courses at various levels, which are aimed at enhancing all students’ STEM education and creating supportive environments for fostering next-generation scientists. Furthermore, efforts built upon the PI’s research aim to connect/demonstrate important topics relevant to undergraduate and graduate education to the enabling broader impacts synthesis and catalysis have on society. In this regard, the PI’s group has had a steady number of undergraduate and graduate scholars as its members. Several members are underrepresented and minority members; examples are Ms. Anisha Tyagi (undergraduate), now in chemistry graduate school, Ms. Desiré Matias (grad student), Ms. Hawa Keita, (current grad student), Mr. Miles Mason (current grad student),  Mr. José Rosario (current grad student), and Mr. Devin Mickles (current grad student).
